# Executive Summary TO UPDATE

<br> Chickaloon Village Traditional Council Environmental Stewardship Department (CVTC ESD, or ESD) has conducted baseline stream water quality monitoring from 2015 to 2023 (ongoing). This report documents and analyzes one year of data from May 2022 (spring breakup) to April 2023....

# Background

<br> Nay’dini’aa Na Kayax (Chickaloon Native Village) is an Ahtna Dene Tribe in southcentral Alaska....<br>


## Project history, objectives, and staff - updated
 
<br> This CVTC Surface Water Quality Monitoring Project provides the only baseline surface water quality data available on many water bodies in the Matanuska Watershed. CVTC has conducted baseline water quality data collection since 2015 with funding from federal grants including  EPA IGAP, BIA Subsistence, and USFWS Tribal Wildlife Grants. Work has been conducted following CVTC-written and EPA-approved Quality Assurance Project Plan (QAPP). The latest CVTC Surface Water Quality Monitoring QAPP was approved on April 27, 2021.
 
*Objective:* 1) To develop a baseline data set of surface water quality in the Matanuska Watershed, from water bodies important to the Tribe and representative of the many types of streams and rivers in the area. 2) To observe and measure trends in natural systems that may occur from natural or anthropogenic influences.  

*Staff:* CVTC Environmental Stewardship Department (ESD) staff working on the project consists of Kendra Zamzow, PhD (Field Sampling Leader/Project Manager) and Jessica Winnestaffer (QA Officer/ESD Director).  Dr. Zamzow updates the QAPP, maintains and calibrates equipment, collects field data, reviews data for accuracy, precision, and completeness, and uploads data to the EPA WQX site.  Jessica assures the QA/QC work has been completed by competent staff and provides  review and edits to the QAPP, data, and reports.  Additional ESD staff members may assist with field data collection or data review. <br>

<br>Threats to water quality include:  

* Resource development, particularly coal and placer mining
* Increasing human population, with growing presence of roads, subdivisions, cabins, and off-road vehicles
* Climate change  

Details of these threats are provided in the "Maps" Appendix.
<br>
<br>


## Project activities and updates - add more?

<br> Activities:

* Develop an accurate, defensible baseline data set of surface water quality 
* Monitor streams for changes in water quality over time
* Maintain a QAPP

Sampling is conducted once a month at every site.  Winter sampling began in winter 2020-2021 and continued through the current year. Annual water quality reports are now provided on a cycle that follows the streams: from May, when breakup typically occurs, to April. This report covers May 2022 through April 2023.<br>

Updates:
<br>
* Water levels were very high in the Matanuska River and in Moose Creek this summer. 

  * The clearwater river side-channel site added last year, Ts'itonhna Channel 44.6 at Milepost 68, was flooded out when the braided river moved into the channel and absorbed it.  This site has been dropped.

  * A different clearwater river side-channel, an important one for traditional harvesting, was added.

  * At the mouth of Moose Creek, floodwaters caused bank erosion and trees on the bank were washed into the creek.  The river plain between the mouth of Moose Creek and Kleinschmidt Slough was changed.
  
  * Despite high waters at Moose Creek, the water level of spring-fed Kleinschmidt Slough (which flows into the mouth of Moose Creek) did not change.

* The YSI 556 field meter used in prior years was replaced by a YSI ProPlus field meter.

* Reports now include information on anadromous fish at the monitored streams, the stream order (with headwater streams being first order), interactive maps as a separate document, and recommendations for future sampling.  

* Maps are now in an appendix instead of in the body of the report. Background information on the watershed, including maps of anadromous waters, is placed with the maps. 

* Tables of data have been added as an appendix. <br>


## Where we go - updated
<br>  
Chickaloon Tribe monitors streams along most of the length of Ts'itonhna, from Sutton to Glacier View, with two sites near Palmer (Map 3.4.1 in Maps appendix). Approximately 18 sites are visited on a monthly basis in summer, with 15 sites monitored monthly in winter (Table 2.4.1). Most streams are sampled at only a single location (Table 2.4.2). All sample sites are on streams that drain directly or indirectly into the Matanuska River (Ts'itonhna).  All but three monitored streams are anadromous for at least part of their length. The three that are not are California Creek, Hicks Creek, and Purinton Creek.  California Creek has a natural barrier to fish passage; Hicks Creek can be turbid for many months which may prevent use; Purinton Creek can be turbid but much less so than Hicks Creek.<br>
<br>
<br>

### *Anadromous fish* - updated
<br>Prior to the arrival of *c’etsiy tnaey* (white people), Ahtna people cared for the streams and, according to oral knowledge, likely enhanced the fish populations. These were reduced with the influx of new people and mining. The Chickaloon River, said to have once had all five species of salmon, now has only coho and chum. The sockeye that are said to have been in the wetlands of upper Moose Creek are not there, and salmon populations are so low that none of the streams of the Matanuska watershed are fished to supply the annual Tribal Culture Camp. 

While some of the population declines stem from historic damage, some are more recent and likely due to a combination of historic damage, current population pressures (habitat degradation, fish passage barriers, poaching), and climate change impacts in the freshwater and marine environments.  Declines in salmon populations led the MSB in 2015 to advocate for and achieve a "conservation corridor” (reducing commercial fishing time in the federal waters in the center of Cook Inlet, an area known as the "Exclusive Economic Zone" (EEZ)) to allow more salmon into MSB streams. Although it may be improving the returns of some salmon populations, especially sockeye, Chinook have declined to where there is no fishing or only catch-and-release. Coho, which form the base of income for sport-fishing guides in the Susitna drainage, are in a steep decline.

# Methods

## What we measure and how we measure it - updated

<br> We collected information using equipment that could be carried in the field and could be used to track the general “health” of the water bodies. No laboratory analysis was performed. 

The YSI 556 field meter used in prior years was replaced by a YSI ProPlus field meter. This was used to measure pH, dissolved oxygen (DO), water temperature, and specific conductance (SC); barometric pressure was noted given its relationship to DO. Each of these is referred to as a "parameter". Readings were recorded at three one-minute intervals; if the readings had not stabilized, the YSI probe was allowed to soak longer and more readings were taken, or a note was made on the field sheet that readings were not stable. To measure water turbidity, a single water sample was collected and split into three vials (“split sample”) or three separate samples were collected (“sequential samples”); the method was identified on the field sheet.  Vials were placed in a Hanna turbidimeter to be measured. 

To avoid problems with water freezing on the threads of turbidity vials and the probe transport cup, vials were kept in an inside jacket pocket and dissolved oxygen was calibrated in a heated vehicle near the sampling site.  

At each site, photographs were taken, weather was documented, stream depth at the YSI field meter probe was recorded, and a site sketch and general comments were often added on field sheets.  Data was recorded on paper field sheets and transcribed later into an electronic database for quality control review and to upload to EPA’s WQX public database, after 100% transcription checks of data sheets.  More detail is available in the 2021 QAPP. <br>

<br>

## How we know if water quality is good - no change

<br>The goal of the project is to determine whether water is of good quality for fish or for drinking or for other ways in which water can be enjoyed, as well as to determine whether there are changes over time in streams. To do this, the data collected in the field is compared to Project Action Limits (PALs).<br>

<br>PALs are water quality measurements that, when exceeded over multiple site visits, trigger an action such as researching why the change might be occurring or alerting agencies. The PALs we have chosen (Table 3.2.1) are based on state of Alaska water quality criteria for use by aquatic life; where there are no state regulations in place, the PAL is based on a change from the baseline data collected to date. A measurement outside a PAL may indicate poor water quality or a deviation from normal observations. For further detail, see the 2021 QAPP. Streams may be good habitat for salmon even when parameters fall outside the PAL, if the excursion outside the PAL is brief or if the fish have evolved to adapt to the conditions.<br>
<br>

**Table 3.2.1. Project Action Limits**
<br>

|Analytical parameter|Project Action Limit or Alaska Water Quality Standard |
|:------------------------|:-------------------------------------------|
|pH|6.5-8.5|
|Dissolved oxygen (%)|No more than 110% saturation|
|Dissolved oxygen (mg/L)|5-17 mg/L, and no less than 7 mg/L in anadromous waters|
|Specific conductance|An increase of 100% or more over the maximum observed in the past in that month|
|Temperature|< 13 ºC in anadromous salmon spawning areas, < 15 ºC in anadromous salmon migratory/rearing areas, < 20 ºC for all waters|
|Turbidity|More than 25 NTU above natural conditions in waters used by fish or wildlife; More than 5 NTU for drinking water when natural turbidity is <50 NTU or <10% increase where natural turbidity is >50 NTU, not to exceed a total increase of 25 NTU.|
|:------------------------|:-------------------------------------------|
<br>
<br>

## Flow determines river "seasons" - updated
<br> To assess parameters across seasons, seasons were defined by the pattern of stream flow (hydrograph). A USGS flow gauge has been operating at Moose Creek since September 1999 (Fig. 3.3.1), and it is the only flow gauge near our sample sites. Based on this, seasons were defined as: <br>
<br>

-   Spring: rising limb of the hydrograph begins around April 15 and completes around June 15 (2 months).
-   Summer: peaks and valleys of a generally descending trend in hydrograph run from June 16 to Sep 15 (3 months)
-   Fall: Declining hydrograph with no peaks runs from about Sep 16 to Nov 15 (2 months)
-   Winter: Flat hydrograph with no peaks or valleys runs from Nov 16 to April 14 (5 months). 
<br>
<br>

# Results - UPDATE IN PROGRESS
<br>
All results are ultimately based on individual readings from streams. At each site, parameters are recorded three or more times during each sample event and these replicates are condensed into an average for that site on that day.  The data presented in this report is based off those "day-means", which can be found in tables in Appendix xx.

The means and medians of parameters are influenced by the number of times and seasons in which monitoring occurred. In particular:

* Buffalo Creek is sampled only in winter
* Ts'itonhna Channel 44.6 (at milepost 68) was sampled only once, in summer, during the water quality year.
* Ts'itonhna Channel 49.0 (at beaver pond culvert) is a new site and has not been sampled in May, June, or July.

## How data is presented - updated
<br> Data is presented 

* By parameter (pH, temperature, dissolved oxygen, specific conductance, and turbidity) shown as boxplots by season and location. Tables that inform this section are in Appendix xx.

* By individual stream site, with boxplot figures for season and month for each parameter at the site. Tables that inform this section are in Appendix xx.

Figures are presented in a way that data from the current water year (May 2022-April 2023) can be compared to the collective data from past years (September 2015-April 2022). Figures also show the Project Action Limits (PALs) for parameters. PALs are values that, if exceeded consistently indicate a possible water health concern. More information on PALs is provided in the 2021 QAPP and in Appendix xx of this report.  <br>

### *pH* - updated
<br> The slightly alkaline character of streams is apparent (Fig. 4.3.1). The upper (alkaline) PAL limit is approached at Hick's Creek and the lower is approached at Buffalo Creek and Moose Creek 11.7. The mean and median by site ranges from pH 7.2 to 8.5 (Table A2.2.1).

Regionally (for all sites aggregated), in WQY2022 seasonal minimums have a wider range (6.1-8.1) but similar maximums relative to the aggregate of past years (Table A2.1.1).  

By site, in general, values were more alkaline in WQY2022 than in the past, except at Wolverine Lake outlet (Fig. 4.3.1). The greatest variability in pH occurs in winter and at sites MOOWTL 0.0, MOOCRK 11.7, and BUFCRK 0.0 (Fig. 4.3.1 and Table A2.2.1).

For WQY2022, the lower PAL limit was reached at Buffalo Creek twice and at Moose Creek 11.7 (upper bridge) once, all in January-February. The upper PAL limit was reached at Hicks Creek five times, throughout the year (Table A1.3.1).<br>

* More spring data is needed.

Notably, 

* the Wolverine Lake outlet site (WOLOTL 1.7) was **not** as alkaline as in the past, and even approached the lower PAL limit. Moose Creek at upper bridge (MOOCRK 11.7) reached the lower PAL limit for the first time. **All** PAL exceedances at Hicks Creek occurred between March 2022 and March 2023.
* the pH **increases** going from upstream to downstream on Moose Creek in WQY2022. This was not observed in WQY2021 or in the aggregate of past years.<br>

### *Temperature* - updated
<br> 
Stream temperatures were on the cool end of the range at sites (Fig. 4.3.2), although warmer (6C) regionally in spring based on means and medians (Table A2.1.2). Spring and fall maximums were less extreme (9C, 8C) than in the past (16C, 13C).  The greatest variability in temperatures occurs in the fall (Fig. 4.3.2).

No temperatures at any site went over 10C in WQY2022, with the exception of Wolverine Lake outlet (WOLOTL 1.7), which exceeded 13C in every summer month. At this site, 13C was exceeded in August, 15C in July, and 20C in June (Table A2.1.2, Table A2.2.2). In the past, exceedances were seen at Granite Creek and Purinton Creek; that was not observed this year.

Notably,

* There continues to be open water in the winter at California Creek (CALCRK 0.0), at Kleinschmidt Slough (KLESPR 0.0), and at the clearwater channel Ts'itonhna Channel 44.6 (TSICHA 44.6) with minimum stream temperatures of 1.2C, 1.8C, and 1.3C respectively.<br>

### *Dissolved oxygen (DO)* - updated
<br> All sites in WQY2022 had DO means and medians above 7 mg/L (Table A2.2.3), with means and medians similar to the past (12-14 mg/L) and maximums similar to the past (14-17 mg/L) (Table A2.1.3). However minimum DO for aggregated sites by season was higher in the spring than in the past (12 mg/L vs 8 mg/L) and summer and fall were slightly lower. In WQY2022 and in the past, the summer and winter minimums has been below 7 mg/L, driven by the Wolverine Lake outlet site (WOLOTL 1.7) (Fig. 4.3.2). In winter, all values at WOLOTL 1.7 were below 7 mg/L (Fig. 4.3.2).

In WQY 2022, DO was generally on the high end of the range (Fig. 4.3.2). The Kleinschmidt Spring (KLESPR 0.0) and Wolverine Lake outlet (WOLOTL 1.7) sites were on the low end of the range in WQY2022, and sites Wolverine Lake outlet (WOLOTL 1.7) and the new site Ts'itohna Channel 49.0 (TSICHA 49.0) had DO values below 7 mg/L. The low oxygen at the Ts'itonhna Channel site could be due to decomposition of many salmon in the shallow, slow-moving water.  The low oxygen at Wolverine Lake outlet has been hypothesized to be due to ice building up over the mucky bottom, limiting oxygen exchange with the surface.

In WQY2022, PAL limits were exceeded once at Ts'itonhna Channel 49 (TSICHA 49.0, in August) and three times at Wolverine Lake outlet (WOLOTL 1.7 in June, November, January) (Table 1.3.2, Sections A3.6 and A3.12). <br>

Notably,

* DO was generally higher than in the past, but lower at WOLOTL 1.7.
* DO was below PAL limits at the new site TSICHA 49.0 in summer.
* DO was below PAL limits at WOLOTL 1.7 at every winter measurement.
<br>


### *Specific conductance (SC)* - updated
<br> When streams are aggregated for a regional view, specific conductance (SC) is generally lower than in the past (as mean, median, and maximum), although the minimums are higher than in past seasons for spring, fall, and winter (Table A2.1.4).

As in the past, streams appear to generally break into three groups, based on mean and minimum values (Table A2.2.4).

* In the past, breakouts (by mean values) were at about < 150 µS/cm, 150-500 µS/cm, and > 500 µS/cm. In WQY2022, breakouts were similar at about < 150 µS/cm, 150-400 µS/cm, and > 400 µS/cm, indicating slightly lower maximum SC values. The streams that fit into each division were the same:

  * Mean > 400 µS/cm at Caribou, Hicks, Purinton Creeks
  * Mean < 150 µS/cm at Eska Creek, Moose Creek, and Buffalo Creek
  * Mean 150-400 µS/cm at all other sites
The new site Ts'itonhna Channel 49.0 (TSICHA 49.0) has mean values over 400 µS/cm, but does not have a full year of data yet. The high mean value for the eastern (Glacier View) sites suggests SC is driven by geology in that area.

In WQY2022, SC was in the range of past years, and has little variability within sites over a season, except at Caribou Creek and Hicks Creek in summer (Fig. 4.3.3). The maximum SC values of all streams aggregated by season were lower than in the past (Table A2.1.4). Seasonal maximums were similar to WQY2021, except that spring had a lower maximum SC.

There are no PAL limits for SC. 

Notably,

* There is little variability at individual sites over a season, except at Caribou and Hicks Creeks in summer.
* Stream sites continue to breakout into defined groups by mean SC values.
* The new site Ts'itonhna Channel 49.0 may have high SC but does not have a full year of data yet.
<br>
<br>

### *Turbidity* - updated
<br> Consistent with past values, turbidity is generally very low (Fig. 4.3.5). When streams are aggregated by season, means were similar to WQY2021, but maximums in WQY2022 were much higher in summer and fall than in WQY2021 (Table A2.1.5). This may be a result of the high flows in streams and rivers in WQY2022.


As in WQY2021, streams appear to generally break into three groups, based on mean turbidity values (Table A2.2.5).

* In WQY2021, breakouts (by mean values) were at about < 25 NTU, 25-100 NTU, and > 100 NTU. In WQY2022, breakouts shifted lower at about < 10 NTU, 10-50 NTU, and > 50 NTU, indicating slightly lower turbidity values. The streams that fit into each division were the same:

  * Mean > 50 NTU at Caribou Creek, Hicks Creek, and Chickaloon River
  * Mean 10-50 NTU at Purinton and Wolverine Creeks
  * Mean < 10 NTU at all other sites
The only change is that Kings River (8 NTU) fit into the mid-range category of turbidity in WQY2021 and into the lowest turbidity category in WQY2022.

In WQY2022, turbidity was similar to past ranges (Fig. 4.3.5). The breakdown of sites grouped by maximum turbidity (Table A2.2.5) was similar to WQY2021 as:

* at or near 1000 NTU at Caribou Creek, Hicks Creek, Purinton Creek, Chickaloon River, Wolverine Creek
* 100-200 NTU at Kings River, Granite Creek, Eska Creek, Moose Creek wetlands, California Creek
* less than 30 NTU at all other sites

There is no PAL for turbidity. In the facet plots, lines are shown at 25 NTU and 500 NTU for easier viewing. 

Notably,

 * Despite near-record high flows, turbidity was at or below 10 NTU at all Moose Creek sites.
 * The high medians and means at Caribou and Purinton Creeks suggests sustained high turbidity events over several months. However, maximums at these two and at Chickaloon River did not exceed 500 NTU in WQY2022 although they exceeded that multiple times in WQY2021.
 * High flows on the Matanuska River caused the river to braid into and consume the clearwater channel site TSICHA 44.6; the river at the location of the former channel had turbidity over 1000 NTU.

## Characterization by stream site - UPDATE 
<br>
For each monitored site, a parameter is shown by month and by season.  Text summarizes information overall, for Water Quality Year 2021, and seasonal trends. Recommendations for continued sampling, or to reduce sampling, are provided.

In the figures, the boxplots represent past years in aggregate and the orange dot represents the values for Water Quality Year 2021. The colored lines represent PAL values.  For SC, there is no PAL value, but a green line is placed at the value of the calibration standard that we use.  The options we have are to use a standard of 447 µS/cm or 1,413 µS/cm. For turbidity there is no PAL value, but lines are placed at 25 NTU and 500 NTU to better bracket very low and high turbidity values.
<br>
<br>

### *Streams from Glacier View to Chickaloon*
<br>

#### Caribou Creek (CARCRK2.8) 
<br>Caribou Creek is a second-order anadromous stream, with chum spawning in the lower reaches (downstream of the Glenn Highway). It is wide, fast, and not wade-able. The sample site CARCRK2.8 is located just upstream of the Glenn Highway. Placer (gold) mines are present further upstream, and a state-designated recreational mining (placer gold) area is located downstream of the site. Nova Guides, a small, local river-rafting and glacier-tour operator, has a summer rafting operation and a designated raft ramp just downstream of the sample site.The site also attracts rock climbers, both the two-legged and four-hoofed ones. Caribou Creek is turbid in summer, and has a cover of thick ice and ice blocks in winter. Winter stream samples are collected at open leads, if present.  <br>
<br>
<br>

**Photo 4.4.1. Caribou Creek.** <br> (Left) Sampling gear at open lead, looking upstream, January 2023. (Right) Nova river rafters preparing to launch, looking downstream from site towards the Glenn Highway bridge over the creek. <br>

```{r Hooray! CARCRK photos side by side}

CARCRK_Photo1<-image_read("~/CNV/WQ monitoring/Baseline stream WQ/WQ monitoring_Reports/2023 WQ report/Images/CARCRK Jan2023.JPG")%>% 
  image_resize("700x700")%>%
  image_border("white", "65x10")
CARCRK_Photo2<-image_read("~/CNV/WQ monitoring/Baseline stream WQ/WQ monitoring_Reports/2023 WQ report/Images/CARCRK Jun2022.JPG")%>% 
  image_resize("800x800")%>%
  image_border("white", "65x10")
image_append(c(CARCRK_Photo1, CARCRK_Photo2))

```
<br>
Caribou Creek is consistently cold with high dissolved oxygen and slightly alkaline pH. There are strong negative correlations between temperature and DO, with more DO in colder water, and between turbidity and specific conductance. This site has some of the most frequent periods of high turbidity and specific conductance of the sites monitored. <br>

For data supporting the following summaries, see figures below and tables in Appendix A2 and A3.1.<br>

In Water Quality Year 2022,

* Data was not collected in December 2022 (Table A3.1.1).

* pH was 8.0 to 8.3 in every month, similar to past years. The minimum pH in WQY2022 was higher in every season than in past years (Table A3.1.1, Table A3.1.3).

* Temperature mean/medians were 1-3C and stream temperatures did not exceed 8C. This is cooler than the aggregate of data from past years (Sep 2015-Apr 2022), and maximums in spring, summer, and fall were cooler than in past years (Table A3.1.2, Table A3.1.4). Temperatures increase steadily from April to July (peaking at 8.2C) and decreased steadily from July to October (Fig. 4.4.1). DO follows the opposite pattern.

* DO never dropped below 11 mg/L, similar to past years (Table A3.1.5).

* SC was high, at 600-800 µS/cm in every month except May and June, when SC dropped slightly to 300-450 µS/cm. The minimum SC (by season) was higher than in past years and the maximum SC lower, so there was less variation overall (Table A3.1.1, Table A3.16). SC progresses to steadily higher values from May to November (Fig. 4.4.1).

* Turbidity was low (less than 10 NTU) November-April and high (over 150 NTU) in May, June, and August. Similar to SC, turbidity was less variable than in past years, with the minimum turbidity higher and maximum turbidity lower than in past years (Table A3.1.7). Maximum turbidity was reached in May at 347 NTU. Turbidity generally mirrored SC, with the exception of a low turbidity point in July.

Notably, 

* No PAL limits were exceeded in WQY2022.
* This site was recommended in WQY2021 for reduced winter sampling after 2-4 more years of data collection.

```{r set up CARCR sum stats, results='hide'}
#This works because we use na.rm=TRUE after each function to perform. We CANNOT use %>% na.exclude after "summarise_each" or it will remove entire rows that have the NA in them.  This was discovered when it became obvious that the "max" CARCR turbidity in the stats table was less than the actual recorded max. It occurred at other site stat tables as well. The "na.exclude" allowed the DO to be calculated, but removed an entire row (date) for all parameters where Turbidity had an NA.  But if na.exclude was not used, it calculated Turbidity correctly but only placed NA for all DO stats.

#Results set to "hide" to prevent a tibble table being generated in the html. So CARCRKsum is separated from the knit.

#rename columns so they do not have a separator _ in the name; otherwise, that is used as by R to say "everything before this becomes a row name and everything after this becomes a column name".  R does this because when we designated "min", "med" etc, it adds _minimum, _median etc to the column name.  Then we can split the column easily into rows and columns.

CARCRKSum22<-CARCRK2022[, 6:12]%>%
  dplyr::select(pH, Temperature_C, Temperature_F, Dissolved_oxygen_mg_L, Specific_conductance_µS_cm, Turbidity_NTU)%>%

  summarize_each(funs("minimum"= min(., na.rm=TRUE),
                "median" = median(., na.rm=TRUE),
                "mean"= mean(., na.rm=TRUE),
                "maximum"= max(., na.rm=TRUE),
                "standard deviation" = sd(., na.rm=TRUE)))%>%
  pivot_longer(everything(), names_sep='_', names_to=c('.value', 'parameter'))
```

#### Hicks Creek (HICCRK0.5)
<br>
Hicks Creek is a wade-able but flashy first-order stream that runs down from mountain canyons and enters the Matanuska River. It is not glacially-fed or anadromous. In winter, it is covered by a thick layer of snow and ice, and water is collected at open leads, if present, or by digging through snow and ice to open a hole using hammer and chisel. As with Caribou Creek, the Glenn Highway passes over the stream just downstream of the monitoring site. Nova Guides, a small, local river-rafting and glacier-tour operator, has a summer rafting operation at the confluence of Hicks Creek and the Matanuska River.<br>

```{r set up HICCR sum stats, results='hide'}
HICCRKSum21<-HICCRK2022[, 6:12]%>%
  dplyr::select(pH, Temperature_C, Temperature_F, Dissolved_oxygen_mg_L, Specific_conductance_µS_cm, Turbidity_NTU)%>%
  rename("pH"=pH, "Temperature (C)"= Temperature_C,  "Temperature (F)" = Temperature_F, "Dissolved oxygen (mg/L)"=Dissolved_oxygen_mg_L, "Specific conductance µS/cm"= Specific_conductance_µS_cm, "Turbidity (NTU)" =Turbidity_NTU)%>%
  summarize_each(funs("minimum"= min(., na.rm=TRUE),
                "median" = median(., na.rm=TRUE),
                "mean"= mean(., na.rm=TRUE),
                "maximum"= max(., na.rm=TRUE),

  summarize_each(funs("minimum"= min(., na.rm=TRUE),

                "maximum"= max(., na.rm=TRUE),
                "standard deviation" = sd(., na.rm=TRUE)))%>%
  pivot_longer(everything(), names_sep='_', names_to=c('.value', 'parameter'))
```

#### Purinton Creek (PURCRK5.2)
<br>Purinton Creek is a shallow, wade-able second-order stream that is not glacial or anadromous, and passes through a meadow wetland upstream of the monitoring site. At the monitoring site, the stream is narrow with willow and alder laced over a pool.  In winter, snowmachines run up the creek near the monitoring site. The monitoring site is at a point where the stream reach is thick with willow and alder reaching over the water. In winter, water is accessed by digging through deep snow and ice. However, sometimes flowing water is not found, or is too deep to access. <br>

**Photo 5.4.4. Purinton Creek.**
<br>(Left) Looking upstream and working on top of the stream in April 2023. A small hole, dug through snow and ice to reach open water, is in front of ESD staff member Laura Junge. (Right) Looking downstream. Open leads are developing in May 2022. <br>

#### California Creek (CALCRK0.0)
<br>California Creek is a narrow, very shallow, wade-able first-order stream that runs down off Castle Mountain in Chickaloon and enters the Chickaloon River. It is not glacial or anadromous. The water quality of this creek would be threatened if coal was mined from Castle Mountain, as it has been in the past; coal exploration was conducted most recently in 2011-2012.

#### Chickaloon River (CHIRVR2.3)
<br>

The Chickaloon River is a fast, deep river that is glacially fed and anadromous. It is one of two third-order streams that are monitored. Prior to coal mining in 1913-1920, the river is reported to have had all five species of salmon; the 2022 Anadromous Waters Catalogue documents only coho and chum salmon. 

The river has high flows in the summer and partial ice cover in winter.  At the monitoring site CHIRVR2.3, the river narrows and then makes a 90-degree turn; standing waves can form in summer and in winter, ice cliffs form across and on the banks of the river, and ice blocks can be pushed up into California Creek. ...<br>
<br>

(Left) At the confluence of California Creek (right side of photo) and chickaloon River, looking downstream from site in January 2023. (Middle) ESD Director Jessica Winnestaffer and ESD staff Laura Junge at Chickaloon River, view is looking downstream from monitoring site, April 2023. (Right) Turbidity in June 2022.

#### Ts'itonhna Channel 44.6 (TSICHA44.6)
<br>Ts'itonhna Channel (at MP 68) is not documented as anadromous but fry were observed there in April and a clearwater channel about two miles upstream is well-documented with spawning sockeye. This is a new site, with data collection beginning in January 2022. 

This clearwater side-channel of the Matanuska River is on a flat area between the river and an embankment to the Glenn Highway.  It is open all winter, and appears to have groundwater input that surfaces about 50 feet upstream of the monitoring site, and groundwater bubbles up from the sand-cobble bottom, forming tiny cones. Many salmon fry were observed in the channel in April. The area was also visited frequently by moose.<br>
<br>

**Photo 5.4.8. Tsi'dektna (clearwater) Channel 44.6.**
<br> High turbidity visually and at the Hanna meter. The Matanuska River had flowed into the channel, June 2023.  In April 2023 there had been extremely clear water and many salmon fry.<br>

### *Streams in Sutton*
<br>

#### Kings River (KINRVR0.1)
<br>Kings River is an anadromous stream used by coho, chum and Chinook for spawning. It originates in the Talkeetna mountains and flows into the Matanuska River. It is one of two third-order streams that are monitored.

Kings River is not wade-able, but the riverbed changes and forms gravel bars and channels that are wade-able.  It is a popular area for camping, although there are no public facilities, and a popular ORV trail is on the north side.  In winter there are frequently open leads, but they are usually within depressions with steep banks, so that accessing water can be a challenge. <br>
<br>

**Photo 5.4.9. Kings River.**
<br> (Left) Looking downstream in August 2022. The monitoring site is upstream of the log. (Middle) Looking downstream from the Glenn Highway bridge at the confluence of Kings River with the Matanuska River. (Right) A section of ice shelf collapsed during sampling, January 2023. <br>

#### Granite Creek (GRACRK0.3)
<br>Granite Creek is a glacially fed second-order stream with coho, chum, king, and pink salmon documented in the 2022 Anadromous Waters Catalogue.

Granite Creek is not wade-able. It originates in the Talkeetna mountains and flows into the Matanuska River at the community of Sutton. It can be flashy in summer. In winter it freezes over, and snowmachines use the creek as a trail; open leads are frequently not present. ...<br>

#### Eska Creek (ESKCRK5.5 and ESKCRK1.7)
<br>
Eska Creek is a second-order wade-able stream that runs through the community of Sutton and empties into the Matanuska River. It is glacially-fed and used by chum, coho, and sockeye salmon for spawning. In the past it was an important traditional salmon harvesting stream for Chickaloon Village Tribal citizens.

There are two monitoring stations on the stream: ESKCRK 1.7, just upstream of the Glenn Highway, and ESKCRK 5.5, further upstream and just upstream of a large fish-passage culvert under Jonesville Road, one of the main roads in Sutton. In winter, the creek freezes over.  ...


**Eska Creek (at upper culvert) (ESKCRK5.5)**
<br>
The upper Eska Creek monitoring site has large boulders and cobble, and small pools between boulders where salmon fry can rest.  It can be too deep and fast to wade across in summer. In past winters, water could be reached at the bottom of steep, snow-filled depressions. 

For Water Quality Year 2022, ....<br>
<br>

**Eska Creek (at Glenn Highway) (ESKCRK1.7)**
<br>
Eska Creek at the Glenn Highway is very shallow, with a gravel bed and no cobble. ORVs drive across the creek about ten feet downstream of the monitoring site.  In summer, adult salmon may be observed migrating. In winter, a thick cover of ice forms with no open leads....<br>

### *Streams on Lazy Mountain*
<br>

#### Wolverine Creek (WOLCRK1.7)
<br>
<br>Wolverine Creek is a fast-flowing stream, although shallow enough to wade across during some winter months.  It is glacially-fed and anadromous; coho spawn in it and Chinook and sockeye are present.  Ice can form completely across the creek in winter at the monitoring site....<br>

**Photo 5.4.13. Wolverine Creek**
<br>
(Left) Looking across at the monitoring site, September 2022. (Right) Looking upstream from the monitoring site. The creek splits around a bar upstream, January 2023.<br>

```{r set up WOLCRK sum stats, results='hide'}
WOLCRKSum21<-WOLCRK2022[, 6:12]%>%

  summarize_each(funs("minimum"= min(., na.rm=TRUE),

                "mean"= mean(., na.rm=TRUE),
```

#### Wolverine Lake Outlet (WOLOTL1.7)
<br>
This small, shallow first-order stream that flows from Wolverine Lake to Wolverine Creek. It is the only lake-associated site that is monitored. Coho salmon and trout spawn in the creek, sockeye spawn in the lake and coho rear in the lake. According to one area resident, several years ago lake residents felt the lake level was too high and removed a beaver dam and the beavers to lower the level. Residents now report that the lake has become very shallow, and they are attempting to dam it to raise the water level. The low lake levels cause the outlet stream to have high water temperatures, often near air temperature.<br>


**Photo 5.4.14. Wolverine Lake Outlet**
<br>
(Left) Shallow, narrow, lush area of the monitoring site in June 2022. (Right) Looking upstream towards the monitoring site in January 2023.  All of the area upstream of the snowmachine bridge may freeze in winter.<br>

### *Moose Creek*

#### Tributaries to Moose Creek
<br>
<br>There are four major tributaries to Moose Creek and all but Premier Creek are part of the water quality monitoring network. (Although Premier Creek is not monitored, one site on Moose Creek is just downstream of the confluence with Premier Creek.) The sites are Moose Creek Wetlands (MOOWTL0.0), Buffalo Creek (BUFCRK0.0), and Kleinschmidt Spring (KLESPR0.0). All are narrow wade-able streams at the monitoring site location.<br>

##### Moose Creek Wetlands (MOOWTL0.0)
<br>
This site is accessed by driving to the end of Buffalo Mine road, climbing over a locked gate at a vehicle bridge over Moose Creek, and walking about ten minutes up a privately-maintained road to the edge of private property. The last several miles of Buffalo Mine Road are privately maintained by one landowner, and an access road from Buffalo Mine Road to the bridge across Moose Creek is maintained by a second landowner. The vehicle bridge runs across the creek for home-owners to access their property; the locked gate prevents the public from using the bridge, however, the land from the bridge to the monitoring site is public.

This un-named stream is narrow with relatively slow flow, although not as slow as the Wolverine Lake Outlet stream....

##### Buffalo Creek (BUFCRK0.0)
<br>Buffalo Creek originates on Wishbone Hill, which is an area that has been mined for coal in the past. The stream would likely be de-watered if coal mining were to start up again. From Wishbone Hill, it enters a floodplain and winds through a wet forested area until it reaches Moose Creek. The site is reached by driving down Buffalo Mine Road to a pullout, then walking down a short, very steep embankment and across a forested floodplain to Moose Creek, which is crossed just downstream of the confluence of Buffalo and Moose Creeks....<br>

<br>Although to date, Buffalo Creek has not exceeded 8C temperature, ....<br>

##### Kleinschmidt Spring (Slough) (KLESPR0.0)
<br>
<br>This site was formerly a lake, which was reduced to a stream when the Matanuska River changed course.  It is spring-fed from hills between the Matanuska River and Glenn Highway, and it flows across a marshy area of moss, grass, and *Equisetum* to the mouth of Moose Creek.  The Kleinschmidt Spring and Moose Creek mouth sampling sites are within a few minutes walk of each other. The area around the outlet of Kleinschmidt, the mouth of Moose Creek, and the Matanuska River is braided and dynamic. There are multiple ancient home sites and cultural artifacts in the area. The spring hosts many spawning chum and sockeye salmon, which can clog the banks of the small stream.

The site is accessed in summer by driving down a dirt track part of the way, and about a 15 minute walk.  In winter, it takes 20-30 minutes each way to snowshoe in down a powerline and the snow-covered track.<br>

<br> This stream and the clearwater channel that was added to monitoring sites this year are the only sites entirely open (no ice cover) in the winter. ... <br>
<br>

```{r set up KLESPR sum stats, results='hide'}
KLESPRSum21<-KLESPR2022[, 6:12]%>%
  dplyr::select(pH, Temperature_C, Temperature_F, Dissolved_oxygen_mg_L, Specific_conductance_µS_cm, Turbidity_NTU)%>%

  summarize_each(funs("minimum"= min(., na.rm=TRUE),
                "median" = median(., na.rm=TRUE),
                "mean"= mean(., na.rm=TRUE),
                "maximum"= max(., na.rm=TRUE),
                "standard deviation" = sd(., na.rm=TRUE)))%>%
  pivot_longer(everything(), names_sep='_', names_to=c('.value', 'parameter'))

  summarize_each(funs("minimum"= min(., na.rm=TRUE),
                "median" = median(., na.rm=TRUE),
                "mean"= mean(., na.rm=TRUE),
                "maximum"= max(., na.rm=TRUE),
```

#### Moose Creek main stem
<br>
<br> Moose Creek is the most important traditional salmon harvesting stream in the area, although it no longer has enough salmon to support Tribal needs. All five species of Pacific salmon spawn in it. 

Moose Creek is a second-order stream that originates in the Talkeetna range, and passes through canyons along its route to the Matanuska River. Moose Creek is wade-able at several locations for at least a few months.  During breakup, the water level rises very quickly (Fig. 5.4.1). <br>

##### Moose Creek at upper bridge (MOOCRK11.7)
<br>The most upstream location where Moose Creek can be accessed is 11.7 km (river miles) upstream from the confluence with the Matanuska River, at the end of Buffalo Mine road. The last several miles of the road are privately maintained by one landowner, and an access road from Buffalo Mine Road to a bridge across Moose Creek that is maintained by a second landowner. The vehicle bridge runs across the creek for home-owners to access their property; a locked gate prevents the public from using the bridge.  The monitored site is about 20 feet downstream of the bridge; although monitoring is normally conducted upstream of bridges, there is a side channel of the creek immediately upstream that makes accessing the main channel difficult.

The creek at this location is lined with boulders, with a few small pools near the shore, and can have high waves in summer.  It is a site where kayakers put in to float the stream. In winter there is a thick layer of ice, and snowmachines will create a track across the creek, usually just upstream and just downstream of the bridge. There is usually open water, although it may be via a sinkhole with steep sides mid-stream. This site is a few minutes walk from the Moose Creek wetlands site.<br>

##### Moose Creek at Premier Mine (MOOCRK6.6)
<br>
<br>Moose Creek near the old Premier Mine is about 5 km downstream from the upper bridge monitoring site.  The stream is wider and much less turbulent at this location. The creek retains some of the glacial-green color, but the clarity is more evident. The site is accessed by driving to the end of the paved (and plowed) part of Buffalo Mine Road, then down a dirt track. In winter, this track is not plowed. It is about a 20 minute snowshoe walk to the site...<br>

```{r set up MOOCRK6.6. sum stats, results='hide'}
                "mean"= mean(., na.rm=TRUE),

  pivot_longer(everything(), names_sep='_', names_to=c('.value', 'parameter'))
```

##### Moose Creek above Glenn Highway (MOOCRK1.4)
<br>
The Moose Creek monitoring site MOOCRK1.4 is located upstream of the Glenn Highway bridge across Moose Creek and at the edge of a small campground maintained by Chickaloon Village. A USGS gauge is located upstream of the site.  The width and depth of Moose Creek at this site are similar to that of MOOCRK6.6. In winter, ice shelves form along the banks but there are usually open leads.<br>

##### Moose Creek at mouth (MOOCRK0.0)
<br>The site at the mouth of Moose Creek is near but upstream of the confluence with Kleinschmidt Spring, and also enters the Matanuska River downstream along a braided gravel plain. The site has low turbidity, and the clarity of the water is evident in winter; in summer there is too much turbulence to see through the water. In summer, salmon, especially Chinook salmon may be seen migrating upstream.  The population of Chinook salmon is still low, and fishing for them is prohibited.<br>
